div.p: >> Hi, this is Joyce Farrell.

Let's
talk about arrays.

An array is a list of
continuous values stored
in computer memory.

Every array has a
specified size.

Every array is made up of a
number of items called elements.

Each element in an array
must have the same data type.

And every element can be
accessed using a subscript.

A subscript is a whole number
value ranging from zero

to one less than the
size of the array.
For example, if you want

to declare a four-element numeric
array, you give it a data type,

num, and
a name like money,

and then you indicate
the size of the array.

In this case, it's
a four-element array,

so four memory locations
are reserved.

The names of those
locations are money[0],
money[1], money[2], and money[3].

The subscripts appearing within
the square brackets range

from zero to one less than
the size of the array.

You can assign a value
to an array element.

For example, perhaps you want
to say money[0] equals 14.

That assigns 14 to
element zero of the array.

You don't have to
assign values in order.

The next statement you make
might be money[3] equals 82,

and that would assign an
82 to the last element
of this array, money[3].

You then might say
money[1] equals 6.

Or you might change a value
at an element in the array

and say money[0] equals
9 and change its value.
You can perform arithmetic;

money[0] plus 10 is
assigned to money[3].
So now money[3] has the value 19.

What happens if you try to
assign money[2] to money[1]?
In this case, it's illegal,

because money[2] has
not been initialized,

so it has garbage value
and cannot be assigned.

How about if you try to
assign 20 to money[4]?

In this case, because
it's a four-element array,

that statement is not valid,
because there is no element 4.

A four-element array only has
spots 0, 1, 2, and 3.

You can initialize an
array when you declare it,
by giving it values to start.

For example, if you want all
zeros, you might make a statement

like num money[4] equals
and then list the zeros.

You can use a loop
with an array,

which is often the
most efficient way
to handle an array.

For example, suppose you declare
a numeric variable named x,
and assign it zero.

Then you could start a loop,
while x is less than 4.
Well, it is because it's zero.

You could assign money[x], which
is money[0], the value zero.

That stores as zero at
the spot money[0].
Then you add 1 to x making it 1,

and reach the end
of the loop body.

When you go to the top
of the loop and check

to see whether x is less than
4, it is, because it's 1,

so you enter the loop
and assign it a zero
to money[x], which is money[1].

Then you add 1 to x making
it 2, and reach the end

of the loop body
and check again.

And since 2 is less than 4,
you enter the loop body again.

You can assign a zero to money[2];
add 1 to x making it 3,
reach the end of the loop body.

3 is less than 4, so you
assign a zero to spot money[3].

Then x becomes 4, and
you reached the end
of the loop body.

Now when you check if x is
less than 4, it's not less
than 4, because it is 4.

So, the loop ends, and you have
successfully assigned zero
to each array element.
Thanks for watching.
